result.execSummary:
The defendant Joseph Emmamuel Harris was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of THC, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Pay $100.00 today.  Balance payable at the rate of $50.00 per month, starting on or before December 1, 2016 and on the same day each month thereafter, until paid in full.  $15.00 payment plan fee added.    Failure to pay any part of the fine or court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Joseph Emmamuel Harris

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Satorius.  Defendant plead to Count 1.  Count 2 dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the count he plead to.  Defendant understood.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant. Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of Possession of THC, contrary to 961.41(3g)(e).  Joint recommendation for a $50.00 fine.  Ordered.  Pay $100.00 today.  Balance to be paid @ $50/mo starting 12/1.    Failure to pay any part of the fine or court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.    Failure to pay any part of the fine or court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.
DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Satorious.  Accepting plea offer.  Set for plea/sentencing today.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

Pre-trial conference on October 19, 2016 at 10:00 am.
Status conference on November 7, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Travis Sartorius.  Waive reading of the complaint.  Defendant stood mute.  NGP entered by the court.  PTC 10/19 and STC 11/7 at 3 pm.
Joseph called @ 8:16 a.m. to inform us that he may be 15 min late; traffic and construction on the road; told him when he gets here to stop at C of C and we can inform court he is here

Joseph called wondered if he had to be here; told him it was mandatory; he stated he was representing himself;he wanted to know charges; I asked if he received the complaint; yes he did; I stated there are 2 charges and stated them; what about the 3rd he said; stated he got 3 tickets; told him I do not know about that; trf his call to the DA's office & I also gave him their number
